typeProperties.script:
parameters{
	UniqueId as string
}
source(output(
		City as string,
		State as string,
		Zip as string,
		Latitude as double,
		Longitude as double,
		Timezone as short,
		DST as boolean
	),
	allowSchemaDrift: false,
	validateSchema: false,
	ignoreNoFilesFound: false) ~> PostalCodes
source(output(
		CustomerKey as integer,
		WWICustomerID as integer,
		Customer as string,
		BillToCustomer as string,
		Category as string,
		BuyingGroup as string,
		PrimaryContact as string,
		PostalCode as string,
		ValidFrom as timestamp,
		ValidTo as timestamp,
		LineageKey as integer
	),
	allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	isolationLevel: 'READ_UNCOMMITTED',
	format: 'table',
	staged: false) ~> DimCustomer
PostalCodes filter(and(
    greaterOrEqual(toInteger(Zip), 90000),
    lesserOrEqual(toInteger(Zip), 98000)
)) ~> PostalCodeFilter
DimCustomer, PostalCodeFilter join(PostalCode == Zip,
	joinType:'inner',
	matchType:'exact',
	ignoreSpaces: false,
	broadcast: 'auto')~> JoinOnPostalCode
JoinOnPostalCode select(mapColumn(
		CustomerKey,
		WWICustomerID,
		Customer,
		BillToCustomer,
		Category,
		BuyingGroup,
		PrimaryContact,
		PostalCode,
		ValidFrom,
		ValidTo,
		LineageKey,
		City,
		State,
		Latitude,
		Longitude,
		Timezone,
		DST
	),
	skipDuplicateMapInputs: true,
	skipDuplicateMapOutputs: true) ~> SelectDesiredColumns
SelectDesiredColumns sink(allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	deletable:false,
	insertable:true,
	updateable:false,
	upsertable:false,
	recreate:true,
	format: 'table',
	staged: false,
	skipDuplicateMapInputs: true,
	skipDuplicateMapOutputs: true,
	errorHandlingOption: 'stopOnFirstError',
	partitionBy('hash', 1)) ~> EnrichedCustomerData
SelectDesiredColumns sink(allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	format: 'parquet',
	partitionFileNames:[(concat('enrichedcustomer_', $UniqueId, '.parquet'))],
	umask: 0022,
	preCommands: [],
	postCommands: [],
	skipDuplicateMapInputs: true,
	skipDuplicateMapOutputs: true,
	partitionBy('hash', 1)) ~> EnrichedCustomerDataAdls

content.query:
-- https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/create-metadata-objects-azure-synapse-serverless-sql-pools/4-create-external-data-sources
-- see sample script at https://github.com/Azure-Samples/Synapse/blob/main/SQL/Samples/LdwSample/SampleDB.sql
-- version 1

-- define database scoped credential
CREATE MASTER KEY ENCRYPTION BY PASSWORD = 'fQv2fKq#FN7r'
CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL [inadaylake] WITH IDENTITY='User Identity' 

-- define datasource location - point to datalake container
IF (EXISTS(SELECT * FROM sys.external_data_sources WHERE name = 'EmployeeDatasource')) BEGIN
    DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE EmployeeDatasource
END
CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE EmployeeDatasource WITH ( 
    LOCATION = 'https://inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net', 
    CREDENTIAL = inadaylake 
); 

-- define formats for files: .csv and .parquet
CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT CsvWithHeaderFormat 
WITH (   
    FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT, 
    FORMAT_OPTIONS ( FIELD_TERMINATOR = ',', STRING_DELIMITER = '', FIRST_ROW = 2   ) 
); 
GO 
CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT ParquetFormat WITH (  FORMAT_TYPE = PARQUET ); 

-- read ad hoc 
SELECT TOP 10 * 
FROM 
    OPENROWSET( 
        BULK 'staging/ir/2021/*/*.csv', 
        DATA_SOURCE = 'EmployeeDatasource', 
        FORMAT='CSV',
PARSER_VERSION='2.0'
    ) AS employees


-- create external table on csv files
IF (EXISTS(SELECT * FROM sys.external_tables WHERE name = 'Employees')) BEGIN
    DROP EXTERNAL TABLE Employees
END
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE Employees ( 
    ID INT,
    FirstName VARCHAR(256) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    LastName VARCHAR(256) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8
    ) 
    WITH ( 
        LOCATION = 'staging/ir/2021/*/*.csv', 
        DATA_SOURCE = EmployeeDatasource, 
        FILE_FORMAT = CsvWithHeaderFormat 
);

SELECT
    COUNT(*)
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net/wwi/factsale-csv/2012/Q1/*/*',
 		FORMAT = 'CSV', 
		FIELDTERMINATOR ='|', 
        FIELDQUOTE = '',
		FIRSTROW = 2
    ) 
WITH 
    (
        SalesKey BIGINT,
        CityKey INT,
        CustomerKey INT,
        BillToCustomerKey INT,
        StockItemKey INT,
        DeliveryDateKey DATE,
        SalesPersonKey INT,
        WWIInvoiceID INT,
        Description VARCHAR(200),
        Package VARCHAR(10),
        Quantity INT,
        UnitPrice DECIMAL(6,2),
        TaxRate DECIMAL(6,2),
        TotalExcludingTax DECIMAL(6,2),
        TaxAmount DECIMAL(6,2),
        Profit DECIMAL(6,2),
        TotalIncludingTax DECIMAL(6,2),
        TotalDryItems INT,
        TotalChillerItems INT,
        LineageKey INT
    ) as S

SELECT 
    CustomerKey, 
    SUM(Quantity) as Quantity
FROM 
    wwi.FactSale
GROUP BY 
    CustomerKey

SELECT  count(*) from wwi_perf.FactSale_Slow

SELECT  count(*) from wwi_perf.FactSale_Fast

SELECT
    FS.CustomerKey
    ,MIN(FS.Quantity) as MinQuantity
    ,MAX(FS.Quantity) as MaxQuantity
    ,AVG(FS.TaxRate) as AvgTaxRate
    ,AVG(FS.TaxAmount) as AvgTaxAmount
    ,AVG(FS.TotalExcludingTax) as AverageSaleWithoutTax
    ,AVG(FS.TotalIncludingTax) as AverageSaleWithTax
    ,COUNT(DISTINCT FS.StockItemKey) as DistinctStockItems
    ,COUNT(DISTINCT DC.Country) as DistinctCountries
FROM
    wwi_perf.FactSale_Slow FS
    join wwi.DimCity DC ON
        DC.CityKey = FS.CityKey
GROUP BY
    FS.CustomerKey

SELECT
    FS.CustomerKey
    ,MIN(FS.Quantity) as MinQuantity
    ,MAX(FS.Quantity) as MaxQuantity
    ,AVG(FS.TaxRate) as AvgTaxRate
    ,AVG(FS.TaxAmount) as AvgTaxAmount
    ,AVG(FS.TotalExcludingTax) as AverageSaleWithoutTax
    ,AVG(FS.TotalIncludingTax) as AverageSaleWithTax
    ,COUNT(DISTINCT FS.StockItemKey) as DistinctStockItems
    ,COUNT(DISTINCT DC.Country) as DistinctCountries
FROM
    wwi_perf.FactSale_Fast FS
    join wwi.DimCity DC ON
        DC.CityKey = FS.CityKey
GROUP BY
    FS.CustomerKey

-- Use poly to load model into the model table
CREATE MASTER KEY ENCRYPTION BY PASSWORD = 'fQv2fKq#FN7r'

-- Create a database scoped credential with Azure storage account key (not a Shared Access Signature) as the secret.
CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL StorageCredential
WITH
IDENTITY = 'SHARED ACCESS SIGNATURE'
, SECRET = 'MXWyVB9TR8oWhOfp4n/KyoH7R+Ucyh3JKdb1NPlCY3NvSxKjM9ZtrWLZX07gB4x68Ow8+cQKV5zP9nMu0qOZaQ=='
;

-- Create an external data source with CREDENTIAL option.
CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE ModelStorage
WITH
( LOCATION = 'wasbs://models@tdetlstore.blob.core.windows.net'
, CREDENTIAL = StorageCredential
, TYPE = HADOOP
)
;
CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT csv
WITH (
FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT,
FORMAT_OPTIONS (
FIELD_TERMINATOR = ',',
STRING_DELIMITER = '',
DATE_FORMAT = '',
USE_TYPE_DEFAULT = False
)
);

--DROP EXTERNAL TABLE [wwi_ml].[MLModelExt]
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE [wwi_ml].[MLModelExt]
(
[Model] [varbinary](max) NULL
)
WITH
(
LOCATION='/hex' ,
DATA_SOURCE = ModelStorage ,
FILE_FORMAT = csv ,
REJECT_TYPE = VALUE ,
REJECT_VALUE = 0
)   
GO

-- Verify access by running query
SELECT Model, 'A simple model.'
FROM wwi_ml.MLModelExt


CREATE TABLE [wwi_ml].[MLModel]
(
[Id] [int] IDENTITY(1,1) NOT NULL,
[Model] [varbinary](max) NULL,
[Description] [varchar](200) NULL
)
WITH
(
DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
heap
)
GO

INSERT INTO [wwi_ml].[MLModel] SELECT Model, 'A linear regression model.' FROM [wwi_ml].[MLModelExt]
SELECT Model, 'A simple model.' FROM [wwi_ml].[MLModel]

/*
Full tutorial available on: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/synapse-analytics/sql/tutorial-data-analyst
In this tutorial, you learn how to perform exploratory data analysis by combining different Azure Open Datasets
using serverless SQL pool and then visualizing the results in Azure Synapse Studio.

In particular, you analyze the New York City (NYC) Taxi dataset that includes:

 - Pickup and drop-off dates and times.
 - Pick up and drop-off locations.
 - Trip distances.
 - Itemized fares.
 - Rate types.
 - Payment types.
 - Driver-reported passenger counts.*/


/*
 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
 * Automatic schema inference  *
 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *

Since data is stored in the Parquet file format, automatic schema inference is available.
You can easily query the data without listing the data types of all columns in the files.
You also can use the virtual column mechanism and the filepath function to filter out a certain subset of files.

Let's first get familiar with the NYC Taxi data by running the following query. */

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc/yellow/puYear=2019/puMonth=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [nyc];


/* Similarly, you can query the Public Holidays dataset by using the following query. */

SELECT TOP 100 * FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/holidaydatacontainer/Processed/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [holidays];

/* Lastly, you can also query the Weather Data dataset by using the following query. */

SELECT
    TOP 100 *
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/isdweatherdatacontainer/ISDWeather/year=2018/month=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [weather];

/* You can learn more about the meaning of the individual columns in the descriptions
of the NYC Taxi, Public Holidays, and Weather Data datasets on the Azure Opendatasets page. */


/*
 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
 * Time series, seasonality, and outlier analysis  *
 * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
You can easily summarize the yearly number of taxi rides by using the following query. */

SELECT
    YEAR(tpepPickupDateTime) AS current_year,
    COUNT(*) AS rides_per_year
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://azureopendatastorage.blob.core.windows.net/nyctlc/yellow/puYear=*/puMonth=*/*.parquet',
        FORMAT='PARQUET'
    ) AS [nyc]
WHERE nyc.filepath(1) >= '2014' AND nyc.filepath(1) <= '2019'
GROUP BY YEAR(tpepPickupDateTime)
ORDER BY 1 ASC;

/* The data can be visualized in Synapse Studio by switching from the Table to the Chart view.
You can choose among different chart types, such as Area, Bar, Column, Line, Pie, and Scatter.
In this case, plot the Column chart with the Category column set to current_year.

From this visualization, a trend of a decreasing number of rides over years can be clearly seen.
Presumably, this decrease is due to the recent increased popularity of ride-sharing companies.
*/


/* For full tutorial click on "?" in top right corner then Knowledge center/Browse Available Samples/SQL Scripts/Analyze Azure Open Datasets using serverless SQL pool*/

IF OBJECT_ID('wwi.DimCity', 'U') IS NOT NULL
    DROP TABLE wwi.DimCity
GO

--Location was eliminated (data type geography not supported)

CREATE TABLE [wwi].[DimCity]
(
    [CityKey] [int] NOT NULL,
	[WWICityID] [int] NOT NULL,
	[City] [nvarchar](50) NOT NULL,
	[StateProvince] [nvarchar](50) NOT NULL,
	[Country] [nvarchar](60) NOT NULL,
	[Continent] [nvarchar](30) NOT NULL,
	[SalesTerritory] [nvarchar](50) NOT NULL,
	[Region] [nvarchar](30) NOT NULL,
	[Subregion] [nvarchar](30) NOT NULL,
	[LatestRecordedPopulation] [bigint] NOT NULL,
	[ValidFrom] [datetime2](7) NOT NULL,
	[ValidTo] [datetime2](7) NOT NULL,
	[LineageKey] [int] NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE
)
GO

IF OBJECT_ID('wwi.DimCustomer', 'U') IS NOT NULL

GO

	[ValidFrom] [datetime2](7) NOT NULL,
	[ValidTo] [datetime2](7) NOT NULL,

    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE

	[FiscalMonthLabel] [nvarchar](20) NOT NULL,

	[FiscalYearLabel] [nvarchar](10) NOT NULL,
	[ISOWeekNumber] [int] NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE
)

GO

	[SaleKey] [bigint] IDENTITY(1,1) NOT NULL,
	[CityKey] [int] NOT NULL,

-- https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/create-metadata-objects-azure-synapse-serverless-sql-pools/4-create-external-data-sources
-- see sample script at https://github.com/Azure-Samples/Synapse/blob/main/SQL/Samples/LdwSample/SampleDB.sql
-- version 1

-- define database scoped credential
CREATE MASTER KEY ENCRYPTION BY PASSWORD = 'fQv2fKq#FN7r'
CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL [inadaylake] WITH IDENTITY='User Identity' 

-- define datasource location - point to datalake container
IF (EXISTS(SELECT * FROM sys.external_data_sources WHERE name = 'SalesDatasource')) BEGIN
    DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SalesDatasource
END
CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE SalesDatasource WITH ( 
    LOCATION = 'https://inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net', 
    CREDENTIAL = inadaylake 
); 

-- define formats for files: .csv and .parquet
CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT BarCsvWithHeaderFormat 
WITH (   
    FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT, 
    FORMAT_OPTIONS ( FIELD_TERMINATOR = '|', STRING_DELIMITER = '', FIRST_ROW = 2   ) 
); 
GO 
CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT ParquetFormat WITH (  FORMAT_TYPE = PARQUET ); 

-- read ad hoc paruqe format
SELECT TOP 10 * 
FROM 
    OPENROWSET( 
        BULK 'wwi/factsale-parquet/2012/*/*/*.snappy.parquet', 
        DATA_SOURCE = 'SalesDatasource', 
        FORMAT='PARQUET' 
    ) AS sales

-- create view
DROP VIEW IF EXISTS SmallSalesP; 
GO 
 
CREATE VIEW SmallSalesP AS 
SELECT *  
FROM OPENROWSET( 
        BULK 'wwi/factsale-parquet/2012/*/*/*.snappy.parquet', 
        DATA_SOURCE = 'SalesDatasource', 
        FORMAT='PARQUET' 
    )
 AS [r];
-- create external table on csv files
IF (EXISTS(SELECT * FROM sys.external_tables WHERE name = 'SalesC')) BEGIN
    DROP EXTERNAL TABLE SalesC
END
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE SalesC ( 
    SaleKey INT,
    CityKey INT,
    CustomerKey INT,
    BillToCustomerKey INT,
    StockItemKey INT,
    DeliveryDateKey DATETIME2,
    SalespersonKey INT,
    WWIInvoiceID INT,
    Description VARCHAR(256) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    Package VARCHAR(32) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    Quantity INT,
    UnitPrice FLOAT,
    TaxRate FLOAT,
    TotalExcludingTax FLOAT,
    TaxAmount FLOAT,
    Profit FLOAT,
    TotalIncludingTax FLOAT,
    TotalDryItems INT,
    TotalChillerItems INT,
    LineageKey INT
    ) 
    WITH ( 
        LOCATION = 'wwi/factsale-csv/2012/*/*/*.csv', 
        DATA_SOURCE = SalesDatasource, 
        FILE_FORMAT = BarCsvWithHeaderFormat 
); 


USE [SqlOnDemand01]; GO 
-- count sales
SELECT  count(*) from [SalesC]

SELECT 
    CustomerKey, SUM(Quantity) AS TotalQuantity, Sum(UnitPrice*TotalDryItems) AS TotalCost
FROM [SalesC]
GROUP BY CustomerKey
ORDER BY 
    [CustomerKey] ASC;
GO

%%pyspark
data_path = spark.read.load(
    'abfss://wwi@inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net/factsale-csv/2012/Q1/*/*',
    format='csv',
    sep="|",
    header=True)

display(data_path.limit(100))
# Model training and registration
This notebook show the process for training the model, converting the model to ONNX and uploading the ONNX model to Azure Storage.

## Explore the training data
The following cells load the source CSV file into a Spark DataFrame and create a temporary view that can be used to query the data with Spark SQL.

df = spark.read.load('abfss://dev@<primary_storage>.dfs.core.windows.net/bronze/wwi-factsale.csv', format="csv"
## Ifheaderexistsuncommentlinebellow
, header=True, sep="|"
df.createOrReplaceTempView("facts")
display(spark.sql("SELECT * FROM facts WHERE `Customer Key` == '11' ORDER BY `Stock Item Key`"))

## Predict Quantity given Customer Key and Stock Item Key
In the following cells we load a subset of the data that just contains the fields needed for training.

from pyspark.sql.functions import col
df3 = spark.sql("SELECT double(`Customer Key`) as customerkey, double(`Stock Item Key`) as stockitemkey, double(`Quantity`) as quantity FROM facts").where(col("quantity").isNotNull())
df3.cache()

Next, we package the data into the format expected by SPark ML's LinearRegression. It requires a DataFrame with two columns- `features` and a column with the labels to predict (`quantity` in this case).

from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler

vectorAssembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols = ['customerkey', 'stockitemkey'], outputCol = 'features')
df4 = vectorAssembler.transform(df3)
df5 = df4.select(['features', 'quantity'])
df5.show(10)
Now, we split our DataFrame into training and testing DataFrames.

trainingFraction = 0.7
testingFraction = (1-trainingFraction)
seed = 42

# Split the dataframe into test and training dataframes
df_train, df_test = df5.randomSplit([trainingFraction, testingFraction], seed=seed)
In the following cell, we train our LinearRegression model.

from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegression

lin_reg = LinearRegression(featuresCol = 'features', labelCol='quantity', maxIter = 10, regParam=0.3)
lin_reg_model = lin_reg.fit(df_train)

print("Coefficients: " + str(lin_reg_model.coefficients))
print("Intercept: " + str(lin_reg_model.intercept))
With a trained model in hand, we can use it to make predictions against the test DataFrame.
df_pred = lin_reg_model.transform(df_test)
display(df_pred)

## Convert model to ONNX
In the cells that follow, we convert the model to ONNX and show how an output of how ONNX represents the Spark ML model.

from onnxmltools import convert_sparkml
from onnxmltools.convert.common.data_types import FloatTensorType

initial_types = [ 
    ("features", FloatTensorType([1, lin_reg_model.numFeatures])),
      #("features", FloatTensorType([None, lin_reg_model.numFeatures])), Miguel tried did not work https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/synapse-analytics/sql-data-warehouse/memory-concurrency-limits#service-levels
    # (repeat for the required inputs)
model_onnx = convert_sparkml(lin_reg_model, 'sparkml GeneralizedLinearRegression', initial_types)
model_onnx

## Upload the model to Azure Storage
In the cells that follow we save the ONNX model to the storage of Spark driver node temporarily. Then we use the Azure Storage Python SDK to upload the ONNX model to Azure Storage.
with open("model.onnx", "wb") as f:
f.write(model_onnx.SerializeToString())

connection_string = "DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=<blob_storage>;AccountKey=<blob_storage_account_key>;EndpointSuffix=core.windows.net"

from azure.storage.blob import BlobClient

blob = BlobClient.from_connection_string(conn_str=connection_string, container_name="models", blob_name="onnx/model.onnx")

with open("./model.onnx", "rb") as data:
    blob.upload_blob(data,overwrite=True)

wwi_sales = spark \
    .read \
    .option("sep","|") \
    .load('abfss://dev@inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net/bronze/wwi-factsale.csv', format="csv", header=True)

wwi_sales = wwi_sales \
    .withColumnRenamed('Sale Key', 'SaleKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('City Key', 'CityKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Customer Key', 'CustomerKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Bill To Customer Key', 'BillToCustomerKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Stock Item Key', 'StockItemKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Invoice Date Key', 'InvoiceDateKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Delivery Date Key', 'DeliveryDateKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Salesperson Key', 'SalespersonKey') \
    .withColumnRenamed('WWI Invoice ID', 'WWIInvoiceID') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Description', 'Description') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Package', 'Package') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Quantity', 'Quantity') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Unit Price', 'UnitPrice') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Tax Rate', 'TaxRate') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Total Excluding Tax', 'TotalExcludingTax') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Tax Amount', 'TaxAmount') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Profit', 'Profit') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Total Including Tax', 'TotalIncludingTax') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Total Dry Items', 'TotalDryItems') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Total Chiller Items', 'TotalChillerItems') \
    .withColumnRenamed('Lineage Key', 'LineageKey')

import numpy as np
from datetime import datetime
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
### Export WWI sales data to parquet files

quarters = 20
start_date = datetime(2012, 1, 1)

for quarter in np.arange(1, quarters + 1):

    quarter_number = 4 if quarter % 4 == 0 else quarter % 4
    end_date = start_date + relativedelta(months=3) + relativedelta(days=-1)
    
    print(f'Exporting data for {start_date.year} Q{quarter_number} ({start_date:%Y-%m-%d} : {end_date:%Y-%m-%d}) ...')

    storage_path_parquet = f'abfss://wwi@inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net/factsale-parquet/{start_date.year}/Q{quarter_number}'

    wwi_sales \
        .where((wwi_sales['InvoiceDateKey'] >= f'{start_date:%Y-%m-%d}') & (wwi_sales['InvoiceDateKey'] <= f'{end_date:%Y-%m-%d}')) \
        .write \
        .partitionBy('InvoiceDateKey') \
        .mode("overwrite") \
        .parquet(storage_path_parquet)

    start_date = end_date + relativedelta(days=1)
### Export WWI sales data to CSV files

quarters = 20
start_date = datetime(2012, 1, 1)

for quarter in np.arange(1, quarters + 1):

    quarter_number = 4 if quarter % 4 == 0 else quarter % 4
    end_date = start_date + relativedelta(months=3) + relativedelta(days=-1)
    
    print(f'Exporting data for {start_date.year} Q{quarter_number} ({start_date:%Y-%m-%d} : {end_date:%Y-%m-%d}) ...')

    storage_path_csv = f'abfss://wwi@inadaylake.dfs.core.windows.net/factsale-csv/{start_date.year}/Q{quarter_number}'

    wwi_sales \
        .where((wwi_sales['InvoiceDateKey'] >= f'{start_date:%Y-%m-%d}') & (wwi_sales['InvoiceDateKey'] <= f'{end_date:%Y-%m-%d}')) \
        .write \
        .partitionBy('InvoiceDateKey') \
        .mode("overwrite") \
        .option("quote", "\u0000") \
        .option("sep","|") \
        .csv(storage_path_csv, header=True)

    start_date = end_date + relativedelta(days=1)

Columns.Name: DunsNumber
Columns.Description: The DUNS number is a nine-digit number issued by Dun & Bradstreet and assigned to each business location in the D&B database having a unique, separate, and distinct operation to businesses for the purpose of identifying them. The number as issued is random and the digits apparently have no significance as to their issuance.

Columns.Name: DunBradstreetSingleLocationSubsidiary
Columns.Description:
There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

NewEntity.Name: Communication
NewEntity.Description: A communication to/from one or more party(s).

Columns.Name: CommunicationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a service request/contact Communication.

Columns.Name: CommunicationStartTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the communication started.

Columns.Name: CommunicationEndTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp when the communication ended.

Columns.Name: CommunicationDescription
Columns.Description: A description regarding the communication.

Columns.Name: CommunicationNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the communication.

Columns.Name: CommunicationQueueTime
Columns.Description: The amount of time that the Inbound Communicator waited in a queue.

Columns.Name: CommunicationHoldTime
Columns.Description: Total amount of time a person is placed on hold during a communication after first being connected to a person. Does not include initial queue time which may have occurred before the initial connection to a person.

Columns.Name: InboundOutboundCommunicationIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the communication is received from the party or sent to the party.

Columns.Name: CommunicationText
Columns.Description:
The text of the communication.   

Depending on the communication type this would be the:

- text of the email or letter
- recorded text conversation of a call

Columns.Name: CommunicationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Communication Method

Columns.Name: CommunicationTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a communication type.

Columns.Name: CommunicationStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Communication Status.

Columns.Name: CommunicationPriorityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Communication Priority.

Columns.Name: IsoLanguageId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an ISO Language.

NewEntity.Name: Customer
NewEntity.Description:
A customer is an individual or legal entity that has or has purchased a product or service.

A potential customer is an individual or legal entity that has the desire to acquire a product or service, the financial ability to pay for that product or service and is located in a location in which the product or service can be delivered to them.

The definition of 'customer' is of critical importance for every organization.    

It is the customer that is the focus of product planning, marketing, sales, service, reporting and analytics.    Without 'customer' there would be no need for the organization to exist since its purpose is to serve the customer and profit from that interaction.

The definition of 'customer' must be consistent with how customers exist and interact with the organization in the real world.  An artificial or conceptual definition of 'customer' that is not consistent with these two objectives is doomed to fail because the data will not be consistent with the definition and employees will not accept concepts or terms that are not consistent with what they see, know and how they interact with customers on a working basis.

Microsoft defines 'customer' to meet these objectives.    When we look out into the real world we see two dominant types of customers:  human beings and legal entities.     

Human beings are obviously male and female individuals of various ages, sex, demographics and a variety of similar dimensions that describe and define them who purchase products, good and services.    

Legal entities are those legally-defined entities such as corporations, partnerships, non-profit organizations, government organizations etc. that purchase products, goods and services.

This view of 'customer' is consistent with the real world and consistent with how employees view and interact with customers.

Of course, that is just the start of identifying, defining and understanding each type of 'customer'.     There is a great deal of detail, complexity and related data that can be used to define each type of customer to various levels of detail and different dimensions of information.

Microsoft implements these detailed concepts and related data via two distinct business area models that expand the coverage and complexity of each type of customer:

-  INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMER Business Area Model
-  LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER Business Area Model

Note:
Each of the Microsoft models - enterprise, business area or data warehouse - have a representative level of detail for the appropriate type of customer, which is a 'subset' of the total data available in the associated INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMER or LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER business area models..   Reference either of those models to expand the coverage or level of detail in each respective data model.

The actual customer implemented in each model depends upon the dominant use of customer for that industry.     

For example, in the pharmaceutical industry the customer is a legal entity, which represents another corporation, company, government organization etc. that purchases the pharmaceutical product and then distributes that product to the end-customer, which is an individual in a retail environment or a government-distribution scheme.    

For this example, the pharmaceutical models will have the legal entity customer represented but not the individual 'end customer' since that is represented in the appropriate retail industry models, which are a different offering.     

Of course, the entire set of data available for a legal entity customer is contained in the associated LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER Business Area Model.   Reference the LEGAL ENTITY CUSTOMER Business Area Model to incorporate additional data that may be of relevance.

In many industries both types of customers are represented since a legal entity or individual can purchase products, goods or services and enter into contracts.    For these industries, both types of customers are represented by some of the more significant or relevant data derived from the associated LEGAL ENTITY or INDIVIDUAL CUSTOMER business area models.   These models can be used to expand the scope or level of detail in any of the enterprise, business area or data warehouse models.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: CustomerEstablishedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Customer relationship was established.

Columns.Name: CustomerTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Type.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: LedgerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger Account.

Columns.Name: CustomerNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Customer.

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: GlobalLocationNumber
Columns.Description: The Global Location Number (GLN) is a simple tool used to uniquely identify locations. It can be used to identify physical locations such as a warehouse, legal entities, or a function / department within a legal entity. The GLN is part of the GS1 system of standards.

NewEntity.Name: Document
NewEntity.Description: A specific physical (written or printed) paper or electronic file that contains information.

Columns.Name: DocumentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Document.

Columns.Name: DocumentName
Columns.Description: The name of the Document.

Columns.Name: DocumentDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Document.

Columns.Name: GlobalDocumentTypeIdentifier
Columns.Description: The Global Document Type Identifier (GDTI) is part of the GS1 system of standards. It is used to identify a document by type or specifically as required.

Columns.Name: DocumentScopeStatement
Columns.Description: The scope of the document.

Columns.Name: DocumentRevisionNumber
Columns.Description: The revision number of the associated document.

Columns.Name: DocumentCreatedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Document was created.

Columns.Name: DocumentCompletedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the document was completed.

Columns.Name: DocumentFiledTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the document was filed.

Columns.Name: DocumentFirstPublishedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the document was first published.

Columns.Name: DocumentMinimumRetentionTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that a document must be retained until. This is typically the earliest timestamp that a document can be deleted and in many cases the timestamp that the document should be deleted.

Columns.Name: DocumentCopyrightTimestamp
Columns.Description: The document copyright timestamp.

Columns.Name: DocumentDeletedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Document was deleted. Once a document is deleted all data associated with the document, attributes of the document (including Document Image) and related entities may be deleted.

Columns.Name: DocumentImage
Columns.Description: The image or text of the document (scanned).

Columns.Name: DocumentText
Columns.Description: The text of the document.

Columns.Name: DocumentNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Document.

Columns.Name: NumberOfPages
Columns.Description: The number of document pages.

Columns.Name: PageSize
Columns.Description: The size of the document pages.

Columns.Name: DocumentUrl
Columns.Description: The URL at which the document is located on the www.

Columns.Name: IsoLanguageId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an ISO Language.

Columns.Name: DeliveryMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a document delivery method.

Columns.Name: DocumentFormatTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a document format type.

Columns.Name: DocumentTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Document Type.

Columns.Name: MediaTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Media Type.

Columns.Name: CountryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Country.

Columns.Name: StateId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a State.

Columns.Name: IdentificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the identification.

NewEntity.Name: Employee
NewEntity.Description: An individual who is hired to provide services to a company on a regular basis in exchange for compensation.

Columns.Name: EmployeeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Employee.

Columns.Name: EmployeeName
Columns.Description: The name of the Employee.

Columns.Name: DateOfBirth
Columns.Description: The date of birth of the employee.

Columns.Name: DateOfDeath
Columns.Description: The date of death of the employee.

Columns.Name: EmployeeStandardCostAmount
Columns.Description: The standard cost for the employee.

Columns.Name: EmployeeOvertimeCostAmount
Columns.Description: The overtime cost for the employee.

Columns.Name: EmployeeHireDate
Columns.Description: The date upon which the Employee was hired.

Columns.Name: HighlyCompensatedEmployeeIndicator
Columns.Description: Highly compensated employees are employees that receive compensation over a certain amount for a specific year.  The amount that qualifies an employee as a 'highly compensated' employee varies from year to year.

Columns.Name: KeyEmployeeIndicator
Columns.Description: An employee who, at any time during the plan year is (1) an officer having annual compensation greater than $130,000 (subject to cost-of-living adjusting), (2) a more-than-5-percent owner of the employer, or (3) a more-than-1-percent owner whose annual compensation exceeds $150,000.

Columns.Name: ExemptEmployeeIndicator
Columns.Description: An exempt employee is an employee who, because of his or her positional duties and responsibilities and level of decision making authority is exempt from the overtime provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Exempt employees are expected, by most organizations, to work whatever hours are necessary to accomplish the goals and deliverables of the position. Thus, exempt employees have more flexibility in their schedules to come and go as necessary to accomplish work than non-exempt or hourly employees.

Columns.Name: NonexemptEmployeeIndicator
Columns.Description: When an employee is classified as nonexempt, it means that the employee is entitled to a minimum wage, and overtime pay at the rate of time and one-half the regular rate for all hours worked in excess of 40 hours per week, as well as other protections under child labor and equal pay as prescribed by the FLSA.

Columns.Name: AlienStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Alien Status.

Columns.Name: SexId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Sex.

Columns.Name: GenderId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Gender.

Columns.Name: RacialCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Racial Category.

Columns.Name: EthnicCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Ethnic Category.

Columns.Name: EmploymentLeadSourceId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Employment Lead Source.

Columns.Name: SecurityClearanceId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Security Clearance.

Columns.Name: SecurityLevelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Security Level.

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Properties.Description: An individual who is hired to provide services to a company on a regular basis in exchange for compensation.

NewEntity.Name: Order
NewEntity.Description: A document or commission by the customer to order products.

Columns.Name: OrderId
Columns.Description: The unique number that identifies an Order.

Columns.Name: OrderConfirmationNumber
Columns.Description: The order confirmation number provided to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: OrderEnteredByEmployeeId
Columns.Description: The employee ID of the employee entering the Order into the order entry system.

Columns.Name: NumberOfOrderLines
Columns.Description: The number of Order Line Items associated with the Order.

Columns.Name: OrderReceivedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Order was received from the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: OrderEntryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The date that the Order was entered into the order entry system.

Columns.Name: CustomerCreditCheckTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Customer/Customer Account had a credit check in regard to the Order amount.

Columns.Name: OrderConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Order was confirmed to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: OrderRequestedDeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Customer/Customer Account requested delivery of the Order.

Columns.Name: OrderCommittedDeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date committed to the Customer/Customer Account for delivery of the Order.

Columns.Name: ShipmentConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that confirmation of the Shipment was made to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: OrderActualDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual timestamp of delivery of the Order to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalRetailPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total list price value of the ordered products = (list price per unit product price)x(quantity ordered) for each line item.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalActualSalesPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total actual price value of the ordered products = (actual selling price per unit product price)x(quantity ordered) for each line item.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalAdjustmentPercentage
Columns.Description: The total percentage of adjustment applied to the Order.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalAdjustmentAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of adjustment applied to the Order.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalAmount
Columns.Description: The total value of the Order including Adjustment(s).

Columns.Name: TotalShippingChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of shipping charge associated with the order.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalTaxAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of all taxes applied to the Order.

Columns.Name: OrderTotalInvoicedAmount
Columns.Description: The total invoiced amount to the Customer/Customer Account = (per units selling price of products)x(quantity purchased) for all line items + all discounts + all rebates + adjustments/credits + taxes

Columns.Name: TotalGratuityAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of gratuity paid.

Columns.Name: TotalPaidAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount including gratuity.

Columns.Name: TotalCommissionsPayableAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of commissions payable and due in regard to the Order.

Columns.Name: SplitCommissionsIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the commissions are to be split between two or more employees.

Columns.Name: OrderBookedDate
Columns.Description: The date signifying that the order has all the needed information to be considered a firm order and to be processed.

Columns.Name: OrderBilledDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Order was billed.

Columns.Name: OrderBacklogReportedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Order backlog was reported.

Columns.Name: OrderBacklogReleasedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Order backlog was released/fulfilled.

Columns.Name: OrderCancellationDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Order was cancelled.

Columns.Name: OrderReturnedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Order was returned.

Columns.Name: ShipmentToName
Columns.Description: The name of the ship-to party.

Columns.Name: ShipmentToLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: ShipmentId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipment.

Columns.Name: CarrierId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Carrier.

Columns.Name: ShipmentMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipment Method.

Columns.Name: RequestedShipmentCarrierName
Columns.Description: The name of the Carrier for the Shipment requested by the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: AlternateCarrierAcceptableIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that an alternate Carrier of the Shipment would be acceptable to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: ActualShipmentCarrierName
Columns.Description: The Carrier of the Shipment.

Columns.Name: ShipOrderCompleteIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Order is only to be shipped when complete - no partial shipments.

Columns.Name: TotalOrderWeight
Columns.Description: The total weight of the Order.

Columns.Name: WeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: TotalOrderFreightChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total order freight charges amount.

Columns.Name: EarliestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The earliest timestamp that the order should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: LatestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The latest timestamp that the order should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: AcknowledgementRequiredIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that an acknowledgement  to the Customer/Customer Account is required for the Order.

Columns.Name: ExpediteOrderIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Order is to be expedited.

Columns.Name: DropShipmentIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Order is to be drop shipped.

Columns.Name: ServiceOrderIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Order is for Service Products.

Columns.Name: ProductOrderIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Order is for Products.

Columns.Name: OrderDeliveryInstructions
Columns.Description: Instructions related to the delivery of the Order.

Columns.Name: CustomerCreditCheckNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Order credit check.

Columns.Name: MessageToCustomer
Columns.Description: A message to the Customer/Customer Account regarding the Order.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: WarehouseId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warehouse.

Columns.Name: StoreId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Store.

Columns.Name: CustomerIdentificationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a customer identification method.

Columns.Name: PoNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Purchase Order.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: SalesMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Sales Method.

Columns.Name: PaymentMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Payment Method.

Columns.Name: BillingCycleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Billing Cycle.

Columns.Name: ContractId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Contract.

Columns.Name: SalesChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: DistributionChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: OrderTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Order Type.

Columns.Name: OrderClassificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Order Classification.

Columns.Name: RejectionReasonId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Rejection Reason.

Columns.Name: OrderProcessingStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Order Processing Status.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: PointOfSaleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Point-Of-Sale.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: VendorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Vendor.

Columns.Name: DeviceId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Device.

Columns.Name: SoftwareProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a software product.

Columns.Name: SoftwareProductVersionNumber
Columns.Description: The version number of the software product.

Columns.Name: PromotionOfferId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion Offer. The Promotion Offer ID is unique to each account or party that is offered to.

Properties.Description: A document or commission by the customer to order products.

NewEntity.Name: RetailProduct
NewEntity.Description:
A product is anything that can be offered to a market that might satisfy a want or need by potential customers.    That product is the sum of all physical, psychological, symbolic, and service attributes associated with it.

There are two basic types of products:

- Tangible (physical)
- Intangible (non-physical) such as services

A service is a non-material or intangible product - such as professional consultancy, maintenance service, repair service etc.
Each product has its own benefits, application, brand name, and packaging that gives it its own identity and distinguishing characteristics.

Every business or organization has business rules that define precisely what a product is.    While we intuitively know what a product is, we must quantify that knowledge and associated business rules with consistent definitions that can be implemented within the organization in strategies and applications.

A product typically goes through five stages of development:

(1) Idea Stage - involving a thorough evaluation of the potential product

(2) Concept Stage - determines customer acceptance by testing and presentation to consumers and distribution channel members.   Specific aspects regarding quality, dependability, reliability, warranty, packaging, service, pricing, terms of sale, sales and distribution channels, advertising and promotions are evaluated.

(3) Product Development Stage - transforms the prototype product into an actual product for mass sale.   This stage requires close interaction between both marketing and manufacturing.

(4) Test Marketing Stage - may or may not be used since it is an expensive and time-consuming process.  Test marketing involves evaluating various product options and alternatives.

(5) Commercialization - It is very expensive to launch a new product so commercialization only applies to those specific products that are actually going to be sold to the market.

Products tend to be categorized as either:  Industrial goods and consumer goods

Industrial goods are used to produce other products .

Industrial goods may be further divided into:

- Raw materials
- Equipment
- Pre-built materials 
- Supplies.

Consumer goods are intended for consumption by the general public.

Consumer goods may be further divided into:

- Durable goods
- Nondurable goods
- Packaged goods

A product may be a member of a product family or product line.

A product family is a grouping of products or services that are related to each other by common function, functionality, design platform or similar characteristics.

Members of a product family frequently have many common parts and assemblies.

Product families are the highest level of grouping for forecasting, capacity planning or related functions.

Ex:
The Apple Macintosh family of products consists of the product lines:
- Mac mini
- MacBook Pro
- Mac Pro

A product line is a grouping of products that are closely related in usage, functionality or marketing characteristics.

A Product Family typically is created to address one or five functions:

1. To increase profits and not erode the sales of existing products

2. To attract additional Markets or Market Segments

3. To counter competitor's products

4. To fill a gap in an existing Product Family.

5. To promote sales of other products in the family line

Line Depth refers to the number of products in the product line.

Line consistency refers to how closely related the products are that make up the product line.

Line vulnerability refers to the percentage of sales or profits that are derived from only a few products in the product line.

Product width refers to the number of different product lines sold by a company.

Product mix refers to the total number of products sold in all product lines.

Line extension refers to the adding of a new product to a line.

"Trading up or brand leveraging" refers to adding a product of better quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

"Trading down" refers to adding a product of lesser quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

If a line of products is sold with the same brand name, this is referred to as family branding.
Strategy and decisions regarding a product line are usually incorporated in a high-level marketing plan addressing product line strategy, sales, channels, distribution channels, pricing and related issues.
A product-line manager is responsible for a product line and supervises several product managers who are responsible for individual products within the line.
Product-line managers typically have the following responsibilities:
- Expansion and composition of a product line
- Evaluate the effects of product mixes on the profitability of other items in the line
- Planning and allocation of resources to individual products in the line
A product is normally associated with a brand strategy - manufacturer, private or generic.

1. Manufacturer-  or 'national' branding in which the brand is assigned by the manufacturer of the Product.

2. Private - or 'dealer' branding in which the brand is assigned by the retailer or wholesaler of the Product.

3. Generic - in which the Product is not marked with any identification.   Generic brands are a means for manufacturers to increase profits by saving on advertising, packaging or other costs associated with manufacturer or private branding.

A brand is name, term, sign, symbol or design or a combination of these which identify the goods or services and differentiate them from those of competitors'

A Trade mark is a brand or some part of the brand that is given legal protection because it is capable of exclusive appropriation and representation.

Manufacturers can use their own brands (known as Manufacturers' brands) or brands of their distributors (Distributors' brands).

Manufacturers/ distributors use brand names for a variety of reasons ranging from simple identification purposes to having legal protection for unique features of the products from imitations.

Brands help consumers recognize certain quality parameters. In some cases, brands are just used to endow the product with unique story and character which itself can be a basis for product differentiation.

Individual brands have their own identity and the corporate or common name is not used to promote its equity.

Individual branding requires more expensive advertising and brand extensive brand creation investments.  By extension, each new brand does not benefit from the positive perceptions of earlier brands.

By contrast, family branding has several advantages.

Each new product is quickly associated with the other products and brand in terms of quality and benefits.

Reduced or eliminated time for name identification and advertising for name recognition purposes.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: ProductName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product, which normally corresponds to the 'marketing name' of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductShortDescription
Columns.Description: The short description of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductInternalName
Columns.Description:
The internal name by which a Product is known.

This normally approximates the business name by which the public identifies the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductModelName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product Model.

Columns.Name: ProductBaseName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product, which normally corresponds to the 'marketing name' of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductCodeName
Columns.Description: The internal code name by which the Product is known within the company.

Columns.Name: ProductIntendedUse
Columns.Description: The intended use of the product.

Columns.Name: IntroductionDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Product was introduced for sale.

Columns.Name: FirstDateManufactured
Columns.Description: The date that the Product was first manufactured by the Manufacturer.

Columns.Name: PlannedAbandonmentDate
Columns.Description:
The planned date to discontinue marketing the product.    

Abandonment is a component in the decline stage of the product's life cycle characterized by a reduced market demand for the product and an increased number of competing products with similar characteristics.

There are three (3) strategies for abandoning a product:

(1)  Reduced marketing and expenditures to maintain profits.

(2)  Concentrating on the strongest market segments and eliminating the weaker market segments

(3)  Maintain the marketing level until the product is discontinued.

Columns.Name: ActualAbandonmentDate
Columns.Description:
The actual date that the marketing of the product was discontinued. 

Abandonment is a component in the decline stage of the product's life cycle characterized by a reduced market demand for the product and an increased number of competing products with similar characteristics.

There are three (3) strategies for abandoning a product:

(1)  Reduced marketing and expenditures to maintain profits.

(2)  Concentrating on the strongest market segments and eliminating the weaker market segments

(3)  Maintain the marketing level until the product is discontinued.

Columns.Name: GlobalTradeItemNumber
Columns.Description:
The Global Trade Item Number (GTIN) is an identifier for trade items that was developed by GS1.

A GTIN can be assigned to only one brick.

Columns.Name: GtinName
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Product GTIN.

Columns.Name: EuropeanArticleNumber
Columns.Description:
A 13 digit barcoding standard which is a superset of the original 12-digit Universal Product Code (UPC).

aka International Article Number (abbreviation of EAN retained)

Columns.Name: UniversalProductCode
Columns.Description:
A system that identifies products by type and by manufacturer.  

A UPC consists of eleven (11) digits.  Six (6) indicate the Manufacturer and five (5) digits describe the product.

UPCs appear on product packages as bar codes, which are graphic symbols that are read by optical scanner devices.   

UPCs are assigned by the Uniform Code Council of Dayton, Ohio.

Columns.Name: GpcBrickId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a GPC Brick.

Columns.Name: ItemElectronicProductCode
Columns.Description:
EPC is the RFID version of the UPC barcode. 
EPC is intended to be used for specific product identification. However, EPC goes beyond UPC by not only identifying the product as an SKU, but also providing access to additional data about the origin and history of the specific units. 
The EPC tag itself identifies the manufacturer, product, version, and serial number. It's the serial number that takes EPC to the next level. 
This is the key to data related to specific lots/batches as well as potentially tracking the specific unit's history as it moves through the supply chain.

Columns.Name: ComponentPartIdentifier
Columns.Description: The Component / Part Identifier (CPID) is used to identify components or parts that are used in the assembly of a larger item. The CPID is part of the GS1 system of standards.

Columns.Name: PluCode
Columns.Description:
The PLU or Price Look-Up code is a 4- or 5-digit number that is primarily used on fresh produce items and will typically appear on a small sticker that is applied to an individual piece of fresh produce. 

The PLU code identifies produce items based upon the commodity, variety and size group. 

They are used by supermarkets to make check-out and inventory control easier, faster and more accurate. 

These numbers are assigned by the International Federation for Produce Standards (IFPS)

Ex: WHITE FLESH PEACHES
PLU Code = 4400

Columns.Name: ProductNetContent
Columns.Description: The standard product length.

Columns.Name: NetContentUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: StorageInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be stored.

Columns.Name: ShelfLifeDays
Columns.Description: The amount of time that a product can be stored before it can no longer be safely consumed or sold.

Columns.Name: ConsumerStorageInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be stored by the consumer.

Columns.Name: ProductShippingInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be shipped.

Columns.Name: ConsumerUsageInstructions
Columns.Description: Statements regarding how the product should be used by the consumer.

Columns.Name: HealthClaimDescription
Columns.Description: A health claim regarding the product as per regulations of the target market.

Columns.Name: MarketingMessageDescription
Columns.Description: A market message that is present on the packaging of the product.

Columns.Name: BundledProductIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether a Product is comprised of a bundle of other Products.

Columns.Name: InformationLabelText
Columns.Description: The label text that identifies the care, use, preparation and handling or the product.

Columns.Name: DescriptiveLabelText
Columns.Description: The label text that describes significant characteristics and benefits.

Columns.Name: WarningInformationText
Columns.Description: The text of the warning label, if any, appearing upon the product.

Columns.Name: GradeLabelText
Columns.Description:
The label text that identifies Product quality with letters, number or conditions.

Examples:

-  Grade A
-  Prime
-  #1

Columns.Name: GovernmentWarningLabelText
Columns.Description: The US Government (or foreign government) label text that addressing the US legal requirements of the Product.

Columns.Name: PatentNumber
Columns.Description: The patent that is associated with the Product.

Columns.Name: PatentDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Patent was granted.

Columns.Name: PatentExpirationDate
Columns.Description: The date that the patent is scheduled to expire.

Columns.Name: Trademark
Columns.Description: A 'trademark' is a brand name or brand mark that is given legal protection.

Columns.Name: ProductLogo
Columns.Description: A design, symbol or series of words that identifies the product.

Columns.Name: ProductSymbol
Columns.Description: A symbol by which the product is known.

Columns.Name: CopyrightNumber
Columns.Description:
The unique identifier (number) of the copyright granted.

A copyright is legal protection given to a work so that it can only be published or sold by the copyright holder.

Columns.Name: CopyrightDate
Columns.Description: The date that the copyright was granted.

Columns.Name: ProductLicenserName
Columns.Description: The name of the company that receives a flat fee or royalty for selling the rights to use a trademark, Patent, manufacturing right or process for the Product.

Columns.Name: EligibleForExportIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the product is eligible for export to foreign countries without restriction.

Columns.Name: ProductExportRestrictionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that exportation of the product is restricted.

Columns.Name: ProductExportRestrictionStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the associated restriction is in effect.

Columns.Name: ProductExportRestrictionEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date for which the associated restriction is in effect.

Columns.Name: ProductExportRestrictionDescription
Columns.Description: A description or statement defining the export restriction(s) placed upon the Product.

Columns.Name: BaseProductQuantity
Columns.Description: The number of base product items contained in the product packaging.

Columns.Name: ProductLength
Columns.Description: The standard product length.

Columns.Name: ProductPlanogramLength
Columns.Description: The standard product length.

Columns.Name: ProductLengthUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductWidth
Columns.Description: The standard product width.

Columns.Name: ProductPlanogramWidth
Columns.Description: The standard product width.

Columns.Name: ProductWidthUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductHeight
Columns.Description: The standard product height.

Columns.Name: ProductPlanogramHeight
Columns.Description: The standard product height.

Columns.Name: ProductHeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductVolume
Columns.Description: The standard product volume.

Columns.Name: ProductVolumeUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductNetWeight
Columns.Description: The net product weight.

Columns.Name: ProductNetWeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductGrossWeight
Columns.Description: The gross product weight.

Columns.Name: ProductGrossWeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ProductDrainedWeight
Columns.Description: The drained product weight.

Columns.Name: ProductDrainedWeightUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: MinimumStorageTemperature
Columns.Description: The minimum temperature at which the product may be stored.

Columns.Name: MinimumStorageTemperatureUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: MaximumStorageTemperature
Columns.Description: The maximum temperature at which the product may be stored.

Columns.Name: MaximumStorageTemperatureUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: MinimumStorageHumidity
Columns.Description: The minimum humidity that the product may be stored at.

Columns.Name: MinimumStorageHumidityUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: MaximumStorageHumidity
Columns.Description: The maximum humidity that the product may be stored at.

Columns.Name: MaximumStorageHumidityUomId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: ReturnPolicyStatement
Columns.Description: A statement detailing the product return policy.

Columns.Name: ReturnPolicyPeriodInDays
Columns.Description: The period in days allowed under the associated return policy.

Columns.Name: ReplacementPolicyStatement
Columns.Description: A statement detailing the product replacement policy.

Columns.Name: ReplacementPeriodInDays
Columns.Description: The period in days allowed under the associated replacement policy.

Columns.Name: ExchangePolicyStatement
Columns.Description: A statement detailing the product exchange policy.

Columns.Name: ExchangePolicyPeriodInDays
Columns.Description: The period in days allowed under the associated exchange policy.

Columns.Name: ProductMustBeDeliveredDaysPriorToExpirationDate
Columns.Description: The number of days prior to the expiration date of the product that the product must be delivered to the an agreed upon point in the distribution system.

Columns.Name: WarrantyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warranty.

Columns.Name: ItemSku
Columns.Description: The Stock Keeping Unit identifier, which is typically used for inventory-related activities.

Columns.Name: PrimaryBrandId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Brand.

Columns.Name: ProductTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product Type.

Columns.Name: PackageTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Package Type.

Columns.Name: PrimaryCountryOfOriginCountryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Country.

Columns.Name: GeographicAreaOfOriginGeographicAreaId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Geographic Area.

Columns.Name: PrimaryColorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a color.

Columns.Name: FlavorTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Flavor Type.

Columns.Name: ScentTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Scent Type.

Columns.Name: SuitableAgeRatingId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a suitable age rating.

Columns.Name: SeasonalUsageId
Columns.Description:
The unique identifier of a seasonal usage for the associated product.

Ex:
- Summer
- Fall
- Winter
- Spring
- All seasons
